Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards a quantitative picture of gene regulation in individual cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the PI will create a quantitative description of the "gene regulation function", i.e. the variation of the transcription of a given gene with the amount of its regulating transcription factor in individual cells. Specifically, the PI will quantify how gene activity, in the form of the discrete time-series of mRNA production events, is modulated by varying concentrations of transcription factors. The PI will examine three paradigmatic gene circuits of increasing organismal complexity, from bacteria to mammals. To perform these measurements, he will use a synthesis of traditional biochemistry and molecular biology techniques, single-cell fluorescence microscopy, advanced image processing and data analysis algorithms, accompanied by coarse-grained theoretical models and stochastic simulations of the underlying kinetics. A significant intellectual outcome of this project will be the first precise quantitative description of the gene regulation function at the level of individual cells, individual transcription events and absolute numbers of proteins and RNA, in genetically unperturbed systems. This mesoscopic description will provide a bridge between two existing levels of description: the molecular (microscopic) level, at which a wealth of information is available, largely through classical biochemistry and biophysics in vitro; and the macroscopic level of gene-network topologies, obtained mostly through classical genetics, but which lacks any quantitative details on the regulatory interactions between elements. The PI and Dr. Sokac in collaboration with Rice University will provide a one-week wet-lab based teaser course for quantitative undergraduates (Q-students) from math, physics, chemistry, computer science and engineering. The goals of the course are to show Q-students how quantitative methods apply to biology, and encourage them to pursue independent research projects. Q-students will be coached on how to find undergrad research positions in labs at the Texas Medical Center, and once placed, they will receive support from mentors and colleagues in a weekly evening discussion group run by the PIs. Ultimately, the goal is to recruit Q-students to careers in biological research.

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAREER: Towards a quantitative picture of gene regulation in individual cells

Gene activity is the prime mover in the living cell, driving a cell's function at any given time. Different gene-expression patterns define distinct cellular behaviors. These expression patterns are the outcome of complex regulatory interactions between multiple transcription factors and the genes whose expression they regulate. However, there is not yet a precise quantitative description of the "gene regulation function", i.e. how the transcription of a given gene varies with the amount of its regulating transcription factor, in the individual cell. This project was aimed at creating such a description. Specifically, we developed tools to measure how gene activity, in the form of the discrete time-series of mRNA production events, is modulated by varying concentrations of transcription factors. We examined three paradigmatic gene circuits of increasing organismal complexity, from bacteria to mammals. To perform the measurements, we used a synthesis of traditional biochemistry and molecular biology techniques, single-cell fluorescence microscopy, advanced image processing and data analysis algorithms, accompanied by theoretical models and computer simulations of the underlying kinetics. 

Intellectual merit: A significant outcome of this project was the first precise quantitative description of the gene regulation function at the level of individual cells, individual transcription events and absolute numbers of proteins and RNA. This "mesoscopic" description provides a bridge between two existing levels of description: the molecular (microscopic) level, and the "macroscopic" level of gene-network topologies. The research also allowed us to address two fundamental questions that are key to the physical understanding of genetic regulation: (1) Universality: To what degree can we find common features in the kinetics of gene expression, and the way it is regulated, across different genes and organisms? (2) Precision: Is gene regulation in the single cell inherently inaccurate ("noisy") due to the ever presence of biochemical stochasticity, or, alternatively, can cells regulate gene activity in a precise (deterministic) manner, which will only be unveiled by an examination at sufficient resolution?

Broader impact: Postdocs and students in the lab pursued research at the interface of physics and the life sciences. Each person's work combined state-of-the-art biological tools (genetics, biochemistry, microscopy) with computational and theoretical tools from engineering and physics. Each postdoc and student received intensive, day-by-day mentoring from the PI on all aspects of the scientific endeavor, to better prepare them for their independence: Planning and executing experiments, writing papers and research proposals, giving presentations, etc. Postdocs and students in the lab also gained teaching experience through a number of avenues. For example, they taught at the annual summer school of the NSF Center for the Physics of Living Cells at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. Broadly, Society as a whole benefited from the scientific pursuit of discovery and from the training of young people in scientific research.
